text: Digital Note: If you want to use a grid to represent your thinking, you can use a "Coordinate Grid" tool or drag one of these grid backgrounds into a "Sketch" or Drawing tool.
Applications
ACE 2-1
Suppose that the polygons below were drawn on centimeter grid paper. How many 1-centimeter cubes (some cut in pieces) would it take to cover each polygon?

a. 12

b. 18.5

c. 28
ACE 2-2

Using the method from Problem 2.1, Darius and Mariana made paper prisms from 4 inch-by-6 inch pieces of paper. One has an equilateral triangle for its base, another has a square base, and the third has a regular hexagon for its base.

To find the areas of the base and top polygons, they traced and measured those figures, as accurately as they could, to get the data shown below. The figures are not drawn to scale.

a. What are the areas of the sides of each prism?

b. What are the perimeters of the bases (and tops) of each prism?

c. What are the areas of the bases (and tops) of each prism?

d. Find the volume of each prism if the height of each one is 4 inches.

e. Do the results in letter d fit the same pattern relating areas and volumes of the prisms from Problem 2.1? Why or Why not?

a. All side areas are 24 in.2

b. All perimeters are 6 in.

c. triangular base area: 1.75 in.2; square base area: 2.25 in.2; hexagonal base area: 2.625 in.2

Note: The height of both the triangle and hexagon is actually ∛, but, in the spirit of what students might measure in a classroom activity, 1.75 is used as an approximation. Students might need a hint to break the hexagon into one rectangle and two triangles or six congruent triangles.

d. triangular prism volume: 7 in.3

square prism volume: 9 in.3

hexagonal prism volume: 10.5 in.3

e. These results are consistent with the pattern relating areas and volumes in the experiments of Problem 2.1, because only the dimensions of the piece of paper the students started with have changed. It shows that the principles involved are independent of specific numerical values.
ACE 2-3
Create a problem based on the surface area of this prism.

Answers will vary.

The surface area of the triangular prism is 8.16m2 :

Triangular “front” and “back”: 2( ½ • 1.6 • 0.6) = 0.96 m2

Rectangular base: 1.6 • 2 = 3.2 m2

2 Rectangular “tops”: 2(1• 2) = 4 m2
ACE 2-4

a. Describe how to find the surface area of any prism.

b. Compare your methods for finding the surface area of any prism with your method for finding the surface area of a rectangular prism.

a. First, you find the area of the base and double that. Then you calculate the area of the rectangle that wraps around the prism, which is the perimeter of the base times the height. Add those two calculations to get the surface area.

b. It is the same general process. The only difference is that the methods for finding the area of the base for a rectangular and a nonrectangular prism.
ACE 2-5
How many unit cubes would you need to fill the prism? Explain your strategy.

To find the volume of the prism we need to find how many cubes sit on the area of the base. Then we find how many layers there are. We can think of B • h=V.

For this triangular prism, B = ½ • 4 • 4. h = 9, so V = (½ • 4 • 4)(9) = 72 cubic units.
ACE 2-6
The diagram below shows a fish tank after a container of water is poured into it.

a. Using the same container, how many containers of water are needed to fill the tank?

b. What fraction of the tank does the container fill?

c. A different container holds 123 cubic inches of water. How many of these containers are needed to fill the tank?

a. 12; The tank’s total height is 8 inches, but it is only filled to a height of 2/3 inch. So, 8 ÷ (2/3) = 12

b. 1/12

c. 768 ÷ 12¾ = 768 ÷ (51/4) = 1024/17 = 60(4/17)
ACE 2-7
Side and top views of a prism whose base and top are equilateral triangles are shown below.

a. What is the surface area of the prism?

b. What is the volume of the prism?

a. Surface area ≈ 3(10)(15) + 2(0.5)(10)(8.7) ≈537 cm2

b. Volume ≈ (43.5)(15) ≈ 652.5 cm3
ACE 2-8

a. What is the volume of the prism?

b. What is the surface area of the prism?

a. Rectangular prism + triangular prism

(4 • 5 • 12) + (½ • 3 • 4 • 12)

240 + 72 = 312 cm3

b. Front and back faces: 2(5 • 4 + ½ • 3 • 4) = 52cm2

Base: 8 • 12 = 96 cm2

Top: 5 • 12 = 60 cm2

Right lateral side: 5 • 12 = 60 cm2

Left lateral side: 4 • 12 = 48 cm2

Total surface area: 52 + 96 + 60 + 60 + 48 = 316 cm2
ACE 2-9

a. Describe how to find the volume of any prism.

b. Compare your methods for finding the volume of any prism with your method for finding the volume of a rectangular prism.

a. Find the area of the base and then multiply that by the height of the prism.

b. It is the same general process. The only difference is that the methods for finding the area of the base for a rectangular and a nonrectangular prism are different.
ACE 2-10
Describe the figure formed by the of slice of the square prism.
ACE 2-11
Describe the figure formed by the of slice of the square prism.
ACE 2-12
Describe the figure formed by the of slice of the square prism.
slanting slice: Different polygons can occur, depending on the angle of the slice. For example, a triangular face will occur if you cut a small pyramid off a corner of the prism.
ACE 2-13
Suppose that you slice the triangular prism as shown below.

a. How many faces will there be on teach figure created by the slice?

b. What polygon appears as a face on the cut of the figure?

a. The vertical cut gives two prisms. One is a triangular prism with 5 faces (3 rectangles and 2 triangles). The other is a prism with six faces (trapezoidal base and top and 4 rectangular faces).

b. Rectangle
ACE 2-14
Match each slice (A. - G.) to the 2-dimensional face that is formed by the slice (a. - g.).
Connections
ACE 2-15
Suppose that you are looking at a building in the shape of a triangular prism.

a. How many vertices, edges, and faces would the prism have?

b. What are the greatest numbers of vertices, edges, and faces you would be able to see? How could you view the prism in order to see the maximum number of vertices, edges, and faces?

c. What are the smallest numbers of vertices, edges, and faces you would be able to see? How could you view the prism in order to see only the minimum number of vertices, faces, and edges?

a. The prism has 6 vertices, 9 edges, and 5 faces.

b. The greatest numbers you could see would be 6 vertices, 8 edges, and 3 faces. To see this much, you could position your eye above and away from the prism in such a way that you are facing directly toward a vertical edge. Other viewing positions are possible.

c. The smallest numbers you could see would be 3 vertices, 3 edges, and 1 face. To see this little, you could position yourself to look directly at the center of the top of the building.
ACE 2-16
Suppose that you are looking at a building in the shape of a prism with regular pentagons for base and top.

a. How many vertices, edges, and faces would the prism have?

b. What are the greatest numbers of vertices, edges, and faces you would be able to see? How could you view the prism in order to see the maximum number of vertices, edges, and faces?

c. What are the smallest numbers of vertices, edges, and faces you would be able to see? How could you view the prism in order to see only the minimum number of vertices, faces, and edges?

a. The prism has 10 vertices, 15 edges, and 7 faces.

b. The greatest numbers you could see would be 9 vertices, 12 edges, and 4 faces, by looking from a location in front of and above one of the vertical faces (so you see the front face, two other lateral faces, and the top).

c. The smallest numbers you could see would be 4 vertices, 4 edges, and 1 face. To see this little, you could position yourself very close to and looking directly at the center of one of the vertical (rectangular) faces.
ACE 2-17
Suppose that you are looking at a large square pyramid.

a. How many vertices, edges, and faces would the pyramid have?

b. What are the greatest numbers of vertices, edges, and faces you would be able to see? How could you view the prism in order to see the maximum number of vertices, edges, and faces?

c. What are the smallest numbers of vertices, edges, and faces you would be able to see? How could you view the prism in order to see only the minimum number of vertices, faces, and edges?

a. The pyramid has 5 vertices, 8 edges, and 5 faces.

b. The greatest numbers you could see would be 5 vertices, 8 edges, and 4 faces. To see this much, you could position your eye above the pyramid looking straight down on it.

c. The smallest numbers you could see would be 3 vertices, 3 edges, and one face. To see this little, you could position yourself very close to and looking directly at the center of one triangular face.
ACE 2-18
The figure below shows a rectangle drawn on a grid of identical squares.

a. What is 3 ½ • 2 ½ ? How does the diagram confirm your result?

b. What is 3.5 • 2.5? How does the diagram confirm your result?

a. 8 ¾ = 35/4 . Each square in the grid is a 1 × 1-square unit. The area of the outlined rectangle is 3 ½ × 2 ½. You can add the square units (6 whole squares) and parts of square units (5 half and 1 quarter) to find the total area, 8 ¾ square units.

b. 8.75 See answer to part (a.) with the additional notation that 0.75 = ¾ as a common fraction.
ACE 2-19
The regular octagon in the figure below is enclosed in a square.

a. Does the calculation 8(0.5 • 3 • 3.6) give the area of the octagon? Why or why not?

b. Does the calculation (7.2 • 7.2) – 4(0.5 • 2.1 • 2.1) give the area of the octagon? Why or why not?

a. Yes. It is the total of areas of eight triangles, each with base 3 and height that is ½ of the 7.2cm.

b. Yes. It is the area of the enclosing square minus the areas of the four corner triangles.
ACE 2-20

Suppose that the design of a package is a triangular prism whose base has area 12 square centimeters and height 15 centimeters. How will the volume of the package change if the design is changed in the following ways:

a. The base is stretched to a similar triangle by a scale factor of 1.5.

b. The base is stretched to a similar triangle by a scale factor of 3.

c. The base is shrunk to a similar triangle by a scale factor of 0.6.

d. The height of the prism is increased by a factor of 3.

e. The height of the prism is increased to 18 centimeters.

a. Volume increases by a factor of 2.25, or 1.52 (to 405 cm3).

b. Volume increases by a factor of 9, or 32 (to 1,620 cm3).

c. Volume reduces by a factor of 0.36, or 0.62 (to 64.8 cm3).

d. Volume increases by a factor of 3 (to 5403).

e. Volume increases by a factor of 18/15 , or 1.2 (to 216 cm3).
ACE 2-21
The figure below shows four rectangles on a grid of squares.

a. Which pairs of rectangles are similar? Explain.

b. Suppose that a fifth rectangle has length 12 and is similar to rectangle D in the figure above. What must be the width of the fifth rectangle?

a. Rectangles A and C are similar because corresponding sides are related by the same scale factor, 2. You can also say that the ratio of length to width in both rectangles is 3 : 2. Rectangles B and D are similar because the scale factor of corresponding sides is 2.5, or because the length-to-width ratio is 2 : 1 in both figures.

b. The width of the fifth rectangle would have to be half the length in order to have the same length-to-width ratio as rectangles D and B. So, the width of the fifth rectangle would be 6.
ACE 2-22

Kwan has two prism-shaped containers. One has a volume of 3 ¾ cubic feet. The other has a volume of 1/3 cubic foot.

a. How many of the smaller container will it take to fill the larger?

b. What operation(s) did you use to find the answer? Explain.

a. 11 ¼ of the smaller container will fit in the larger container.

b. Possible answer: Division (3 ¾ ÷ 1/3 ) because we want to know how many times a smaller number fits into a larger number.
ACE 2-23

Antonia has two prism-shaped containers. One has a volume of 2⅖ cubic feet. The other has a volume of 2/3 cubic foot.

a. How many of the smaller container will it take to fill the larger?

b. What operation(s) did you use to find the answer? Explain.

a. 3⅗ of the smaller container will fit in the larger container.

b. Possible answer: Division (2⅖ ÷ ⅔) because we want to know how many times a smaller number fits into a larger number.
ACE 2-24
A square prism was cut out of a rectangular prism. Now we have this shape.

tiles.title: Square Prism Cut From Rectangular Prism

text:
a. What was the volume of the prism before the cut out?

b. What is the volume now?

c. What was the surface area of the prism before the cut out?

d. What is the surface area now?
a. If the shape had been a rectangular prism, it must have been a 12 m by 6 m by 8 m prism. The volume would be: 12 • 6 • 8 = 576 m3

b. The square prism that was cut out is 4m by 4m by 6m or 96m3

The new volume would be 576m3 – 96m3 = 480m3

c. Front and back: 2(12 • 8) = 192 m2

Right and left lateral sides: 2(6 • 8) = 96 m2

Base and top: 2(12 • 6) = 144 m2

Total Surface Area: 192 + 96 + 144 = 432 m2

d. The surface area lost three 4 by 4 squares. So, the new surface area is: 432 – 3(4 • 4) = 384 m2
Extensions
ACE 2-25
Use the three given views of a three-dimensional figure to sketch the figure itself. Then, find its volume.

Sketches will vary. Possible sketch:

Volume: between 7 and 9 cubic units

(Note: There may be some hidden blocks.)
ACE 2-26
Use the three given views of a three-dimensional figure to sketch the figure itself. Then, find its volume.

Sketches will vary. Possible sketch:

Volume: between 10 and 12 cubic units

(Note: There may be some hidden blocks.)
ACE 2-27

a. What is the volume of this mountain chalet?

b. If you could only have 1 person for every 15m3 to meet fire safety standards, how many people could stay in the mountain chalet?

c. How much longer would the mountain chalet need to be to meet the safety requirements to accommodate 16 people?

a. 71 m3 The volume is ½ • 5 • 7.1 • 4 = 71

b. 4 people. 71 ÷ 15 = 4.7333…

c. The chalet would need to be a little less than 4 time the current length. 16 people would require 16 • 15 m3 or 240 m3. If we divide the needed volume of 240 by the area of the front of the chalet (½ • 5 • 7.1), we get about 13.53. So, the length would have to increase from 4m to just a little longer than 13½ .
ACE 2-28

Leonhard Euler made contributions in many areas of mathematics. One of his most widely known discoveries is a formula relating the vertices, edges, and faces of solid figures like prisms and pyramids.
a. Record data about figures you have studied in a table like the one above.

b. Study the data to see if you can discover Euler’s Formula relating the number of vertices V, edges E, and faces F in figures such as the prisms and pyramids you have studied.

c. Test your ideas by counting vertices, faces, and edges on other solid figures that have polygonal faces.

b. Euler’s formula is expressed in a variety of algebraically equivalent ways. One is E = V + F – 2.

c. The formula holds for any solid with polygonal faces. For example, a pyramid with pentagonal base has 6 vertices, 10 edges, and 6 faces; and 10 = 6 + 6 – 2.
